title: Baseline Calibration: Core Brain Performance Characterization
description: Establishes baseline performance metrics for all core brain types (optimal, probabilistic, personality variants, random). This foundational experiment provides reference distributions against which all future strategies will be compared. Uses solo play to isolate pure strategy performance without opponent effects.
author: simulation-framework
assumptions: Each game is statistically independent given different seeds
Brain implementations are deterministic given the same RNG state
Score distributions are approximately normal for sufficient sample sizes
Solo play reflects inherent strategy quality without opponent interaction effects
limitations: Solo play may not predict head-to-head performance
Personality brains have internal randomness that increases variance
Does not test adaptation to opponent behavior

hypotheses.null: The optimal brain produces the same mean score as the random brain
hypotheses.alternative: The optimal brain produces a higher mean score than the random brain
hypotheses.rationale: Optimal play should dramatically outperform random; this validates basic brain functionality

hypotheses.null: The professor personality produces the same mean score as carmen
hypotheses.alternative: The professor personality produces a higher mean score than carmen
hypotheses.rationale: Professor is designed as analytical/optimal-leaning; should outperform risk-seeking carmen

hypotheses.null: All personality profiles have equal score variance
hypotheses.alternative: Carmen has higher score variance than professor
hypotheses.rationale: Risk-seeking behavior should produce more variable outcomes

hypotheses.null: Optimal brain achieves upper bonus at the same rate as random
hypotheses.alternative: Optimal brain achieves upper bonus at a higher rate than random
hypotheses.rationale: Optimal strategy should prioritize the valuable 35-point bonus
